intro: Scilla pumila, commonly known as the dwarf scilla, is a small bulbous plant native to southern Europe and parts of North Africa. It typically grows to a height of about 10–20 centimeters, with narrow, grass-like leaves and clusters of blue to violet bell-shaped flowers. The plant thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade. It is often found in rocky or limestone habitats, where it forms dense colonies. Scilla pumila is a hardy perennial that blooms in early spring, making it a valuable addition to rock gardens and woodland settings.
